bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Eugenia Hook Carter, April 15, 1900

div1.p: Carter offers his observations of Havana.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Eugenia Hook Carter, April 15, 1900
div1.p:
I ought to have stopped & written to you
last night - but I will have another
chance tomorrow & avail myself of it.,
I was on the Prado last night with Dr Gor-
gas. Thursday & Friday of this week are
holidays, & up to last year no vehi-
cle of any kind was allowed
to run after 12, Thursday. That is
why when Gen'l Lee' left. Brunner et als.
had to leave their baggage behind,
& walk - carrying the children to the wharf.
Now the day is observed: but cabs etc
run same as ever.

Every body in Habana, was out last
night- walking in the square. The
men sat down - 10 cents per chair - & the
ladies walked by in review-all
kinds & classes- about 10,000 of them
I don't think I ever saw so many woman
together at one time. A regular parade
& a very pretty
sight; not The same
“motif” that makes the “afternoon
parade” on Canal street.

A serious: set purpose to enjoy them-
selves in company with the feeling conscious
that consciousness (occasionally mistaken)
that they are admired & that it is admiration
is enjoyable. Im It may be that it withto this
is added the unselfish pleasure in the
pleasure they bestow on the sitters in
chairs! It may be.

Ask mother if she remembers the old
churn-sweep which was under the Aspen-
tree - (cut down in /65), west of the shed-Pa's
shed?. I dreamt about it last night, & it
was as vivid to me this morning as it
was when I was 4 or 5 years old. When I thought
what a wonderful see-saw it would
make. The life at, N. River - as it was when I
was young - was pleasanter I think - quietly happier-
-than any life that I can conceive of now in the
U. S. Still from its nature, it could not endure,

Have to send you
soon as I can get N. Y. ex-
change.

will get a chance & write you a letter soon. This went close to Calato
this boat.
